thread.section_title: Interviews - Golf - Sports - The Times of India
thread.title: Bae ready for Presidents Cup, but doubts linger
thread.title_full: Bae ready for Presidents Cup, but doubts linger - The Times of India

author: timesofindia.indiatimes.com
title: Bae ready for Presidents Cup, but doubts linger
text:
SEOUL: South Korean PGA golfer Bae Sang-Moon arrived home Wednesday for next week's Presidents Cup, amid lingering doubts over his participation in the prestigious tournament.
Bae, 29, recently lost a legal battle to defer his mandatory military service, and it remains unclear just how soon he may be forced to switch his golf kit for army fatigues.
A two-time PGA Tour winner, Bae failed to qualify automatically for the International team that will vie with the US team in the October 6-11 event in the western port city of Incheon.
International team captain Nick Price made Bae one of his two extra picks, saying he wanted a player that South Korean fans could root for.
Although Price said he did not foresee any problem with Bae's availability, there remains an outside chance he could be ordered to report for military duty in the next few days.
"I can't really tell you at this point what will happen," Bae told reporters as he arrived at Incheon airport.
"It's not as though I can just pick a date I want and enter the armed forces," he was Quote: d as saying by the Yonhap news agency.
The golfer said he would meet with officials soon to discuss his case, but appeared confident that he would be able to participate in the Presidents Cup.
Bae said he met Price last week and thanked him for including him as a captain's pick.
"I said I will try not to disappoint him. I told him I'll try to be a big part of the International team," he added.
Nearly every able-bodied South Korean man between the age of 18 and 35 is required to complete around two years of military service.
Anyone refusing faces a prison term of up to three years.
Bae, who made his PGA Tour debut in 2012, earned his permanent US residency in early 2013, but he was ordered to return home after his overseas travel permit expired at the end of last year.
South Korea's military manpower agency rejected the golfer's request for an extension and Bae -- ranked 85th in the world -- said the issue had made it difficult to focus on his game this season.
"Things didn't always go the way I wanted. There were times when I was suffering and sometimes could not sleep," he said.
